headline: Break Out the Blini! Here’s How to Eat Caviar at Home.
description: While you can certainly just eat caviar off a spoon, this simple preparation is a delicious way to dress it up.
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon  crème fraîche or sour cream
1 ounce caviar of your choice (e.g. Kaluga, Osetra, American)

recipeInstructions.name: Step 1
recipeInstructions.text: Remove the tin of caviar from the refrigerator. Allow it to sit at room temperature with the lid on while you prepare the toast.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 2
recipeInstructions.text: Use a chef’s knife to trim off the crust of the bread, then place it in the toaster on the lightest setting. Once the toast has just begun to turn very pale golden, remove and set it on the cutting board. Once the toast has cooled, cut it into 4 triangular pieces by making an “X” cut. (Diagonal slices that cross in the middle).

recipeInstructions.name: Step 3
recipeInstructions.text: Divide the crème fraîche or sour cream between the 4 pieces and use your butter knife to spread to the edges. Don’t add the cream while the toast is warm, or it will melt.

recipeInstructions.name: Step 4
recipeInstructions.text: Use the spoon to divide the caviar among the four toasts, and sprinkle the fresh chives over the top. Serve with lemon wedges for an optional small squeeze of juice just before eating.

name: Break Out the Blini! Here’s How to Eat Caviar at Home.

author.name: Rochelle Bilow
author.description: Rochelle Bilow is a graduate of the French Culinary Institute, and the former social media manager at Bon Appétit and Cooking Light magazines. She has also worked as a cook on a small farm in Central New York and a Michelin-starred restaurant in New York City. Her first book, a food and farming memoir titled The Call of the Farm, was published in 2014. Her second book, a romance novel set in Scotland, will be published in February 2023.
